problem: An isosceles trapezoid has sides of length 4 cm, 10 cm, 16 cm and 10 cm. What is the area of this trapezoid, in square centimeters?
solution:
We drop an altitude from either vertex of the shorter base, forming a right triangle with hypotenuse of length 10 and one leg of length $(16 - 4)/2 = 6$. The remaining leg, which is the height of the trapezoid, is thus 8.

Therefore, the area of the trapezoid is $\frac{4 + 16}{2}\cdot 8 = \boxed{80}$ square centimeters.
model_solution:
Find the height of the trapezoid.
Draw a perpendicular from a vertex on the shorter side to the longer side to find the height.
Use the Pythagorean theorem to find the height: height = √(16² - (10/2)²) = √(256 - 25) = √231.
Use the formula for the area of a trapezoid: A = (1/2) × (sum of parallel sides) × height = (1/2) × (4 + 10) × √231.
Calculate the area: A = (1/2) × (4 + 10) × √231 = (1/2) × 14 × √231 = 7 × √231 ≈ 7 × 15.236 ≈ 106.55.
Simplify the expression: A = 7 × √231 = 7 × √(3 × 7 × 11) = 7√(3 × 11 × 7) = 7√231√7
Multiply 7 by √231: 7√231.
Multiply 7 by √231: 7√231 = 7√(3 × 7 × 11).
Multiply 7 by √231: 7√231 = 7√(3 × 7 × 11) = 7√(3 × 77) = 7√231 = 7√(3 × 7 × 11).
7 × √231 = 7 × √(3 × 7 × 11) = 7√231.
steps: Find the height of the trapezoid.
Draw a perpendicular from a vertex on the shorter side to the longer side to find the height.
Use the Pythagorean theorem to find the height: height = √(16² - (10/2)²) = √(256 - 25) = √231.
Use the formula for the area of a trapezoid: A = (1/2) × (sum of parallel sides) × height = (1/2) × (4 + 10) × √231.
full_steps: Find the height of the trapezoid.
Draw a perpendicular from a vertex on the shorter side to the longer side to find the height.
Use the Pythagorean theorem to find the height: height = √(16² - (10/2)²) = √(256 - 25) = √231.
Use the formula for the area of a trapezoid: A = (1/2) × (sum of parallel sides) × height = (1/2) × (4 + 10) × √231.
